The world needs more Cyber experts.
Young persons in Africa need more training and more job opportunities. People like Khady.
I recently met her in Dakar, Senegal. She is 21 years old, finishing university and on top of this she is getting additional training and networking
opportunities through an initiative from
: the program is called â€œAfrican Girls Can Codeâ€.

Private companies likeandare supporting financially and through
. One big focus of the program is
.

Khady is one of hundreds of women all over Africa taking part. She applied right away when she saw the advert. She wants to use the mentoring with accomplished women from all around the world in tech and cybersecurity, pick up additional skills at coding camps and build a professional life around IoT and Cybersecurity.

We hear lots of complaints from rich countries about the lack of skilled workers. Here is the solution: train them!

Content:
It was a great honor to be interviewed by one of the leading journalists in the Kingdom of Morocco, Saad Bouzrou, of Le360 journal. Saad and I spent a lot of time discussing Artificial Intelligence, the projects I led at New York Universityand their impact, recommendations for young Moroccans interested in AI, and we also spoke about life advices from my late mother, Rachida Bargach. Additionally, we talked about the beautiful and inspiring spots in Tangier where I spend time, such as Cap Spartel and the Rmilat Forest. Special thanks toand his excellent team atjournal.

Title of the Interview in English: "My recipe for success is based on ingredients deeply rooted in our Moroccan values."

Enjoy the interview.

Author:
CEIMIA
CEIMIA

Content:
There's a lot of talk around artificial intelligence... 
- Some people talk about it because it's popular, others because they believe in it; 
- some people are subconsciously subjected to it, others know how to deal with the ethical issues that AI raises...
- some people use it out of necessity, in the quest for the common good and cognitive justice; others use it for capitalist ends.
What is the best approach for Africa, to navigate this dual character of AI, to make it a tool for Africans that meets their needs first and foremost?
As an initial response, I invite you to read my correspondence published this morning in Nature Human Behaviour: We need a decolonized appropriation of AI in Africa.
Here is the link:

Content:
African organisations face higher susceptibility to phishing attacks, with a 36.7% Phish-prone Percentage (PPP) compared to the global average of 34.3%. KnowBe4's 2024 report highlights the need for robust security awareness training to mitigate cyber risks in Africa.

"Cybersecurity challenges in Africa require a combination of regulation, guidelines and security awareness training. Particular focus is needed on threats like deepfakes used for political manipulation, especially ahead of major elections in various African countries. More public-private partnerships are essential to build capacity, address the skills shortage, and improve resilience in the digital world. Investing in Africaâ€™s youth and providing cybersecurity training opportunities can fill the skills gap and also address youth unemployment," remarked Anna Collard, senior vice-president of content strategy & evangelist Africa at KnowBe4.

Content:
My latest report on the Sahel
Abstract: 
Jihadis groups operating in the Sahel have developed combat techniques that imply the use of motorbikes to surprise government forces deployed in the territory. Motorbikes allow them to carry out rapid attacks and to disappear swiftly after. Confronted with a fast-moving lightweight enemy, the armies of the Sahelian countries and the forces of the international coalitions, are ill equipped and are not able to move as fast. Even air cover is, most of the times, inefficient against flocks of motorbikes that scatter under the cover of forests and bushes.
Confrontations between security forces and terrorists take place, in most cases, in locations where specific conditions are met. These conditions are offered for example by forests, for cover, hills, for rapidly vanishing into paths that cannot be taken by four-wheeled vehicles, and rivers that, when crossed, allow the terrorists to gain significant distance and time on their pursuers. In the Sahel, there are numerous examples of these natural characteristics near the borders between two or more countries. One of the most important of these areas is the Liptako-Gourma region, also known as the Sahel tri-border area. Fighters of various affiliation that engage in combat, often receive reinforcements that come from a neighbouring country. Reinforcements are able to cover important distances in a relatively short time onboard motorcycles or pickups.
Terrorist groups' characteristics vary. Sometimes, motorcycles are escorted and supported by pickups. Some other times, groups converge to an established rally point, and, only then, when they have reached a certain number of members, launch their attack. Reading these characteristics can help security forces understand the probable affiliation of the group and, most importantly, their intentions. Terrorists seem to be procuring their motorbikes by stealing them from the local population or by looting premises of government administration or military bases, and also, by smuggling them mainly from Nigeria and Togo.

Content:
How are cyber threats evolving in Africa for 2024? Kaspersky 's recent insights shed light: cybercrime continues its surge across the continent. In South Africa alone, IoT attacks skyrocketed by 28% in Q3 2023. Meanwhile, phishing attacks surged by 134%, a worrisome trend seen in other regions too. Notably, Africa witnesses significant attacks on industrial control systems (ICS), impacting crucial sectors like energy and manufacturing.

What's the advice? Kaspersky's principal cybersecurity researcher,emphasises proactive measures: anticipate state-sponsored cyber-attacks and an AI-driven surge in spear-phishing. To counter these, businesses must adopt robust technologies like threat feeds, advanced security systems, and incident response solutions. It's time to fortify defenses against evolving cyber threats!

Read more:
